elements.content: Three novel bimetallic hybrid crystals featuring rubidium–alkaline-earth metal pairs and trifluoroacetato ligands were synthesized, and their utility as self-fluorinating single-source precursors to the corresponding mixed-metal fluorides was demonstrated. Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O, RbCa­(tfa)3, and RbSr2(tfa)5 (tfa = CF3COO–; tfaH = CF3COOH) were synthesized in both single-crystal and polycrystalline forms via solvent evaporation. Their crystal structures were solved using single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD), and chemical purity was confirmed using thermal analysis (TGA/DTA). Metal–oxygen–metal connectivity in Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O was restricted to four-metal building blocks. In contrast, RbCa­(tfa)3 and RbSr2(tfa)5 were found to be extended inorganic hybrids (Cheetham et al. Chem. Commun. 2006, 0, 4780−4795 ) exhibiting infinite metal connectivity in three and two dimensions, respectively. Systematic analysis of the coordination modes of the trifluoroacetato ligand revealed its ability to bridge alkali and alkaline-earth metals. Rietveld analysis of powder X-ray diffraction data (PXRD) showed that thermal decomposition of Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O and RbCa­(tfa)3 under inert atmosphere yielded crystalline RbMgF3 and RbCaF3, respectively. This solid-state transformation occurred without the need for an external fluorinating agent because the trifluoromethyl group acted as a built-in fluorine source. Solid-state and solution thermolysis of Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O provided access to the hexagonal and cubic polymorphs of the fluoroperovskite RbMgF3, respectively. Findings reported in this article highlight that bimetallic trifluoroacetates offer unique features from the standpoint of both crystal lattice topology and reactivity.

elements.content: In 2006, Cheetham, Rao, and Forster classified hybrid organic–inorganic materials using the dimensionality of the organic and inorganic sublattices as metrics. Within this classification, extended inorganic hybrids are defined as materials featuring infinite bonding connectivity of the metal atoms in at least one dimension. This is achieved, for example, via metal–oxygen–metal bridges in which the bridging oxygen belongs to the organic moiety. Metal connectivity and amenability to compositional tuning make extended inorganic hybrids attractive materials for applications relying on metal-to-metal energy-transfer and long-range charge-transport (e.g., hybrid light emitters and electroactive microporous solids). Bimetallic hybrids offer the additional advantage of complementary functionalities provided by two distinct metals (e.g., sensitizer–emitter and redox-active pairs).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In 2006, Cheetham, Rao, and Forster classified hybrid organic-inorganic materials using the dimensionality of the organic and inorganic sublattices as metrics. Within this classification, extended inorganic hybrids are defined as materials featuring infinite bonding connectivity of the metal atoms in at least one dimension. This is achieved, for example, via metal-oxygen-metal bridges in which the bridging oxygen belongs to the organic moiety. Metal connectivity and amenability to compositional tuning make extended inorganic hybrids attractive materials for applications relying on metal-to-metal energy-transfer and long-range charge-transport (e.g., hybrid light emitters and electroactive microporous solids). Bimetallic hybrids offer the additional advantage of complementary functionalities provided by two distinct metals (e.g., sensitizer-emitter and redox-active pairs).

elements.content: Fluorinated monocarboxylates such as trifluoroacetates have been employed as ligands to generate low-nuclearity bimetallic molecular complexes that serve as precursors for the gas-phase deposition of functional films. Limited consideration has been given to the possibility of utilizing those ligands to generate fluorinated bimetallic extended inorganic hybrids. A search of the Cambridge Structural Database reveals that less than a dozen extended inorganic hybrids incorporating trifluoroacetato ligands have been reported. Researchers have been deterred from using trifluoroacetato bridges on the assumption that monocarboxylates’ rigidity and tendency to chelate a single metal rather than bridge two metals may restrict the range of compositions and structural motifs that form in any particular system. Instead, they have leaned toward geometrically flexible ligands featuring multiple coordination sites and positional freedom of the coordinating atoms (e.g., fluorinated diketonates). Nevertheless, our group has recently demonstrated the electronic and geometric versatility of the trifluoroacetato ligand. We have shown that this ligand bridges metal pairs spanning a broad range of Lewis acidities and sizes; examples include Na–Mn­(II), K–Mn­(II), Rb–Mn­(II), Cs–Mn­(II), Mg–Mn­(II), and Ca–Mn­(II) pairs. The structural motifs of the resulting fluorinated bimetallic hybrid crystals range from monomers and polymeric metal clusters to extended inorganic hybrids with two- and three-dimensional metal–oxygen–metal connectivity. Additionally, reactivity studies show that thermolysis of these crystals under inert atmosphere delivers not only the two metals in a predesigned ratio but also the fluoride anion, which results from the decomposition of the trifluoromethyl groups. In this way, bimetallic trifluoroacetates function as self-fluorinating single-source precursors for mixed-metal fluorides, eliminating the need for an external fluorine source (e.g., fluorinated gas or liquid at high pressure and/or temperature).

elements.content: In this article we extend the palette of fluorinated bimetallic hybrids that can be accessed using trifluoroacetato as a bridging ligand. As a follow-up of our work on alkali–manganese­(II) and alkaline-earth–manganese­(II) trifluoroacetates, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and reactivity of bimetallic trifluoroacetates incorporating rubidium–magnesium, rubidium–calcium, and rubidium–strontium pairs. Three new trifluoroacetates of formulas Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O, RbCa­(tfa)3, and RbSr2(tfa)5 (tfa = CF3COO–; tfaH = CF3COOH) are synthesized in both single-crystal and polycrystalline forms. Their crystal structures are described with emphasis on the connectivity of the metal centers, the dimensionality of the metal sublattice, the coordination modes of the trifluoroacetato ligand, and the presence of metal–organofluorine interactions. Finally, we investigate the reactivity of rubidium–alkaline-earth trifluoroacetates under nitrogen atmosphere and their transformation to the corresponding mixed-metal fluorides in the solid-state and in solution. Results from structural analyses and thermolysis experiments highlight the potential of fluorinated monocarboxylates as ligands to build bimetallic extended inorganic hybrids and of bimetallic trifluoroacetates as self-fluorinating single-source precursors to mixed-metal fluorides.
elements.clean_text: In this article we extend the palette of fluorinated bimetallic hybrids that can be accessed using trifluoroacetato as a bridging ligand. As a follow-up of our work on alkali-manganese(II) and alkaline-earth-manganese(II) trifluoroacetates, we report the synthesis, crystal structure, and reactivity of bimetallic trifluoroacetates incorporating rubidium-magnesium, rubidium-calcium, and rubidium-strontium pairs. Three new trifluoroacetates of formulas Rb2Mg2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅3H2O, RbCa(tfa)3, and RbSr2(tfa)5 (tfa = CF3COO-; tfaH = CF3COOH) are synthesized in both single-crystal and polycrystalline forms. Their crystal structures are described with emphasis on the connectivity of the metal centers, the dimensionality of the metal sublattice, the coordination modes of the trifluoroacetato ligand, and the presence of metal-organofluorine interactions. Finally, we investigate the reactivity of rubidium-alkaline-earth trifluoroacetates under nitrogen atmosphere and their transformation to the corresponding mixed-metal fluorides in the solid-state and in solution. Results from structural analyses and thermolysis experiments highlight the potential of fluorinated monocarboxylates as ligands to build bimetallic extended inorganic hybrids and of bimetallic trifluoroacetates as self-fluorinating single-source precursors to mixed-metal fluorides.

elements.content: Rb2CO3 (99.8%, Sigma-Aldrich), MgCO3 (99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich), CaCO3 (99.995%, Sigma-Aldrich), SrCO3 (99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich), and anhydrous CF3COOH (99%, Sigma-Aldrich) were used as received. Double-distilled water was employed as the solvent. A 1:1 (v/v) mixture of double-distilled water and CF3COOH was prepared in a 50 mL two-neck round-bottom flask. A total of 0.5 mmol of Rb2CO3 and 1 mmol of MCO3 (M = Mg, Ca, Sr) were added to 6 (Mg, Ca) or 3 mL (Sr) of this mixture. Clear solutions were obtained upon quantitative dissolution of the metal carbonates. Crystallization of rubidium–alkaline-earth trifluoroacetates was accomplished by solvent evaporation, which was induced by flowing dry nitrogen gas over the solution. Reaction flasks were immersed in a sand bath at 65 °C, and solvent evaporation took place for 48 h. A needle-valve rotameter was employed to regulate the nitrogen flow rate, which was maintained constant at ∼140 mL min–1 in all cases. After 48 h, reaction flasks were removed from the sand bath, and nitrogen was flowed for an additional 24 (Ca) or 72 h (Mg, Sr). Polycrystalline solids were obtained and kept under static nitrogen atmosphere. Single crystals were recovered from the bulk for structure determination.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Crystal Growth of Bimetallic Trifluoroacetates

Rb2CO3 (99.8%, Sigma-Aldrich), MgCO3 (99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich), CaCO3 (99.995%, Sigma-Aldrich), SrCO3 (99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich), and anhydrous CF3COOH (99%, Sigma-Aldrich) were used as received. Double-distilled water was employed as the solvent. A 1:1 (v/v) mixture of double-distilled water and CF3COOH was prepared in a 50 mL two-neck round-bottom flask. A total of 0.5 mmol of Rb2CO3 and 1 mmol of MCO3 (M = Mg, Ca, Sr) were added to 6 (Mg, Ca) or 3 mL (Sr) of this mixture. Clear solutions were obtained upon quantitative dissolution of the metal carbonates. Crystallization of rubidium-alkaline-earth trifluoroacetates was accomplished by solvent evaporation, which was induced by flowing dry nitrogen gas over the solution. Reaction flasks were immersed in a sand bath at 65 °C, and solvent evaporation took place for 48 h. A needle-valve rotameter was employed to regulate the nitrogen flow rate, which was maintained constant at ~140 mL min-1 in all cases. After 48 h, reaction flasks were removed from the sand bath, and nitrogen was flowed for an additional 24 (Ca) or 72 h (Mg, Sr). Polycrystalline solids were obtained and kept under static nitrogen atmosphere. Single crystals were recovered from the bulk for structure determination.

elements.content: Single-crystal XRD analysis was carried out using a Bruker X8 Apex single-crystal diffractometer. Colorless crystals with approximate dimensions 0.45 × 0.15 × 0.06 (Mg), 0.36 × 0.09 × 0.08 (Ca), and 0.41 × 0.25 × 0.24 mm (Sr) were selected for structure determination and mounted in Paratone N oil. The deliquescent nature of all samples required special handling: crystals were mixed with Paratone oil under nitrogen atmosphere prior to mounting. X-ray intensities were measured at 100 K using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Frames were integrated using the Bruker SAINT software. Experimental data were corrected for Lorentz, polarization, and absorption effects; for the latter, the multiscan method was employed using Bruker SADABS software. Crystal structures were solved using (i) a dual space approach as implemented in SHELXT, and (ii) difference Fourier maps during least-squares refinement as embedded in the SHELXL-2014/7 software running under ShelXle. Structures were visualized using the VESTA software. Hydrogen atoms in Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O were observed within the first few unexplained difference electron density maxima in ΔF maps. Then, they were placed at geometrically suitable positions and refined riding on the parent oxygen atom in the case of tfaH ligands. In the case of water molecules, they were located at the observed positions and refined with restrained O–H bond distances (0.83(2) Å) and H–O–H angles (1.33(4) Å H···H distance). In all cases, the isotropic displacement parameter for the hydrogen atom (U iso H) was constrained according to U iso H = 1.5 × U eq O, where U eq O is the equivalent isotropic displacement parameter of the parent oxygen atom. summarizes crystal data for Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2·­3H2O, RbCa­(tfa)3, and RbSr2(tfa)5. Full details on the data collection, structure refinement, and structural data are given in the Supporting Information (Tables S1–S11, Figures S1–S3). Crystal data were deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with numbers 1579987 (Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O), 1578539 (RbCa­(tfa)3), and 1853038 (RbSr2(tfa)5).

elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis (TGA/DTA)

Simultaneous thermogravimetric and differential thermal analyses were conducted using an SDT Q600 TGA-DTA analyzer (TA Instruments). ~3-5 mg of sample were heated at 35 °C for 30 min under flowing nitrogen (100 mL min-1), and then ramped to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1.

elements.content: EGA analysis was performed by coupling an SDT Q600 analyzer to a MAX300–CAT quadrupole mass spectrometer (Extrel CMS). Ten milligrams of RbCa­(tfa)3 were heated at 35 °C for 30 min under flowing argon (100 mL min–1), and then ramped to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1. Electron impact (70 eV) was employed to ionize the volatile products of the solid-state decomposition. Scans were performed in the m/z range between 10 and 120.
elements.clean_text:
Evolved Gas Analysis (EGA)

EGA analysis was performed by coupling an SDT Q600 analyzer to a MAX300-CAT quadrupole mass spectrometer (Extrel CMS). Ten milligrams of RbCa(tfa)3 were heated at 35 °C for 30 min under flowing argon (100 mL min-1), and then ramped to 600 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1. Electron impact (70 eV) was employed to ionize the volatile products of the solid-state decomposition. Scans were performed in the m/z range between 10 and 120.

elements.content: Decomposition of the bimetallic trifluoroacetates in the solid state was carried out in a tube furnace under flowing nitrogen (100–220 mL min–1). ∼5–20 mg of sample were placed in an alumina boat, and the temperature was ramped at a rate of 10 °C min–1. Target temperatures and dwelling times were 800 °C for 60 min (Mg), 600 °C for 15 min (Ca), and 600 °C for 60 min (Sr). In the case of rubidium–strontium trifluoroacetate, thermal analyses and solid-state decomposition experiments were conducted on polycrystalline samples synthesized using a starting mixture containing 0.25 mmol of Rb2CO3, 1 mmol of SrCO3, 1.5 mL of CF3COOH, and 1.5 mL of double-distilled water.
elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Decomposition

Decomposition of the bimetallic trifluoroacetates in the solid state was carried out in a tube furnace under flowing nitrogen (100-220 mL min-1). ~5-20 mg of sample were placed in an alumina boat, and the temperature was ramped at a rate of 10 °C min-1. Target temperatures and dwelling times were 800 °C for 60 min (Mg), 600 °C for 15 min (Ca), and 600 °C for 60 min (Sr). In the case of rubidium-strontium trifluoroacetate, thermal analyses and solid-state decomposition experiments were conducted on polycrystalline samples synthesized using a starting mixture containing 0.25 mmol of Rb2CO3, 1 mmol of SrCO3, 1.5 mL of CF3COOH, and 1.5 mL of double-distilled water.

elements.content: Solution decomposition experiments were carried out by thermally decomposing 1 mmol of polycrystalline Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O in a mixture of oleic acid (OA), oleylamine (OM), and 1-octadecene (ODE). Oleic acid (90%, Sigma-Aldrich), oleylamine (70%, Sigma-Aldrich), and 1-octadecene (90%, Sigma-Aldrich) were used as received. Standard Schlenk line manipulations were followed throughout. In a typical synthesis, 1 mL of OA, 5 mL of OM, and 5 mL of ODE were added to a 50 mL two-neck round-bottom flask containing the bimetallic trifluoroacetate precursor. The reaction mixture was heated at 115 °C under vacuum (∼2 mTorr) and vigorous magnetic stirring for 1 h. Then, the atmosphere was switched to nitrogen, a thermocouple was placed inside the flask in direct contact with the reaction mixture, and the temperature was increased to 290 °C. Heating was stopped after 2.5 h, and the reaction mixture was quenched to room temperature using a stream of air. The resulting crystals were precipitated with excess ethanol, centrifuged at 8000 rpm, resuspended in a minimum amount of toluene, and reprecipitated using a methanol–ethanol mixture. Centrifugation at 8000 rpm followed by drying at room temperature under vacuum yielded a white powder that was used for XRD studies.
elements.clean_text:
Solution Decomposition

Solution decomposition experiments were carried out by thermally decomposing 1 mmol of polycrystalline Rb2Mg2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅3H2O in a mixture of oleic acid (OA), oleylamine (OM), and 1-octadecene (ODE). Oleic acid (90%, Sigma-Aldrich), oleylamine (70%, Sigma-Aldrich), and 1-octadecene (90%, Sigma-Aldrich) were used as received. Standard Schlenk line manipulations were followed throughout. In a typical synthesis, 1 mL of OA, 5 mL of OM, and 5 mL of ODE were added to a 50 mL two-neck round-bottom flask containing the bimetallic trifluoroacetate precursor. The reaction mixture was heated at 115 °C under vacuum (~2 mTorr) and vigorous magnetic stirring for 1 h. Then, the atmosphere was switched to nitrogen, a thermocouple was placed inside the flask in direct contact with the reaction mixture, and the temperature was increased to 290 °C. Heating was stopped after 2.5 h, and the reaction mixture was quenched to room temperature using a stream of air. The resulting crystals were precipitated with excess ethanol, centrifuged at 8000 rpm, resuspended in a minimum amount of toluene, and reprecipitated using a methanol-ethanol mixture. Centrifugation at 8000 rpm followed by drying at room temperature under vacuum yielded a white powder that was used for XRD studies.

elements.content: PXRD patterns were collected using a Bruker D2 Phaser powder diffractometer operated at 30 kV and 10 mA. Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) was employed. A nickel filter was utilized to remove Cu Kβ radiation. Diffractograms were collected in the 10–70° 2θ range using a step size of 0.012° and a step time of 1.5 s.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD)

PXRD patterns were collected using a Bruker D2 Phaser powder diffractometer operated at 30 kV and 10 mA. Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) was employed. A nickel filter was utilized to remove Cu Kβ radiation. Diffractograms were collected in the 10-70° 2θ range using a step size of 0.012° and a step time of 1.5 s.

elements.content: Rietveld analysis of PXRD patterns was conducted using the General Structure Analysis System (GSAS) with the graphical user interphase (EXPGUI) software. The following parameters were refined: (1) scale factor for each crystalline phase; (2) background, which was modeled using a shifted Chebyschev polynomial function; (3) peak shape, which was modeled using a modified Thompson–Cox–Hasting pseudo-Voight function; (4) lattice constants; (5) atomic coordinates when allowed by symmetry; and (6) an isotropic displacement parameter (U iso) for the major crystalline phase. For minor phases (ca. 5 wt % or less) atomic coordinates and isotropic displacement parameters were not refined; the latter were fixed at 0.010 Å2. Difference curves and R wp and χ2 residuals were employed to assess the quality of the refined structural models.

Rietveld Analysis

Rietveld analysis of PXRD patterns was conducted using the General Structure Analysis System (GSAS) with the graphical user interphase (EXPGUI) software. The following parameters were refined: (1) scale factor for each crystalline phase; (2) background, which was modeled using a shifted Chebyschev polynomial function; (3) peak shape, which was modeled using a modified Thompson-Cox-Hasting pseudo-Voight function; (4) lattice constants; (5) atomic coordinates when allowed by symmetry; and (6) an isotropic displacement parameter (U iso) for the major crystalline phase. For minor phases (ca. 5 wt % or less) atomic coordinates and isotropic displacement parameters were not refined; the latter were fixed at 0.010 Å2. Difference curves and R wp and χ2 residuals were employed to assess the quality of the refined structural models.

elements.content: Crystal structures of Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O, RbCa­(tfa)3, and RbSr2(tfa)5 are depicted in . Rb–Mg and Rb–Ca trifluoroacetates feature a 1:1 alkali-to-alkaline-earth ratio that makes them ideal candidates as single-source precursors to mixed-metal fluorides RbMgF3 and RbCaF3. Attempts to isolate a bimetallic trifluoroacetate crystal featuring the Rb–Sr metal pair in a 1:1 ratio were unsuccessful. Coordinated water and tfaH are observed in Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O. On the other hand, both RbCa­(tfa)3 and RbSr2(tfa)5 are anhydrous, although water was present throughout crystal growth. Similarly, no coordinated solvent molecules were observed in Sr­(tfa)2, Ba­(tfa)2, Na2Mn2(tfa)6­(tfaH), and CsMn­(tfa)3 crystallized via solvent evaporation under flowing nitrogen. Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O, RbCa­(tfa)3, and RbSr2(tfa)5 all crystallize in monoclinic space groups. The building block of Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O consists of four-metal units of alternating Rb1–Mg2–Mg1–Rb2 polyhedra that share edges (Rb1–Mg2), corners (Mg1–Mg2), and faces (Rb2–Mg1) (a). Rubidium atoms are coordinated by both oxygen and organofluorine, while magnesium atoms are octahedrally coordinated solely by oxygen. Positional disorder is observed for atom Rb2 and trifluoroacetato ligands tfa­(A), tfa­(B), tfaH­(G), and tfaH­(H). Rotational disorder is observed for several trifluoromethyl groups. Four-metal building blocks are connected to each other via trifluoroacetato ligands and hydrogen bonds that involve both protonated trifluoroacetato and acuo ligands (b). The metal–oxygen–metal connectivity in the resulting crystal structure is restricted to the building blocks. By contrast, RbCa­(tfa)3 and RbSr2(tfa)5 are extended inorganic hybrids with infinite metal–oxygen–metal connectivity in three and two dimensions, respectively. RbCa­(tfa)3 consists of infinite chains of alternating Ca1–Ca2 corner-sharing polyhedra (c). Calcium atoms are coordinated by oxygen in octahedral (Ca1) and square antiprismatic geometry (Ca2). Positional disorder is observed for trifluoroacetato ligands tfa­(A) and tfa­(C) along with rotational disorder of the corresponding trifluoromethyl groups. Calcium chains extend along the c axis and are connected by Rb–O/F polyhedra with which they share corners and edges (d). Rb–O/F polyhedra are isolated from each other. Finally, RbSr2(tfa)5 consists of corrugated sheets of edge- and face-sharing Sr–O/F polyhedra (e). These polyhedra form an open framework in which 10-membered rings can be identified (f). The formation of similar frameworks was reported by our group in Sr­(tfa)2 and Ba­(tfa)2. Strontium atoms are coordinated by oxygen (Sr1) or by oxygen and organofluorine (Sr2). Unlike the bimetallic trifluoroacetates containing Rb–Mg and Rb–Ca pairs, neither positional nor rotational disorder are observed in RbSr2(tfa)5. Corrugated sheets of Sr–O/F polyhedra extend in the bc plane imparting infinite two-dimensional metal–oxygen–metal connectivity. Irregularly shaped Rb–O/F polyhedra sit above and below these sheets and connect to them by sharing corners, edges, and faces with Sr–O/F polyhedra. Corrugated sheets are stacked along the a axis (g) and are connected to each other via two rubidium–organofluorine bonds; these are Rb1–F1A (3.17 Å) and Rb1–F1B (3.25 Å). This finding underscores the role of metal–organofluorine interactions in determining the topology of the hybrid crystal lattice by affording saturation of the large rubidium cation. More importantly, the synthesis of alkali–alkaline-earth trifluoroacetates and their crystal structures demonstrate that halogenated monocarboxylates can be used as ligands to generate organic–inorganic hybrids featuring infinite connectivity of the metals in at least one dimension. We add that in the course of exploratory syntheses we discovered a hybrid of formula Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6·H2O featuring rings in which 16 metal atoms are connected via metal–oxygen–metal and metal–fluorine–metal bridges (CCDC number 1870532, see Tables S12–S16 and Figures S4 and S5).

elements.content: The versatility of the trifluoroacetato ligand is at the origin of its ability to afford bimetallic extended inorganic hybrids. This is counterintuitive because monocarboxylates are usually thought of as geometrically rigid ligands with a strong tendency to chelate a single metal rather than bridging two metals. This idea has deterred researchers from utilizing monocarboxylates to build extended inorganic hybrids. Analysis of the coordination modes of the trifluoroacetato ligands reveals their ability to accommodate the electronic and geometric requirements of mono- and divalent cations spanning a broad range of Lewis acidities and sizes. Thirteen different trifluoroacetato coordination modes are encountered in alkali–alkaline-earth hybrids synthesized in this work; these are summarized in . Coordination modes differ in bridge index (μ), denticity, and ligating atoms (κ) and include monodentate, bidentate, bridging, and bridging–chelating. Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O exhibits seven coordination modes (vs two for RbCa­(tfa)3 and five for RbSr2(tfa)5). Two features are worth highlighting: (1) the presence of trifluoroacetato ligands capable of bridging four metal centers (μ4) in RbCa­(tfa)3 and RbSr2(tfa)5, which is rather uncommon; and (2) the coordination of the metals by fluorine atoms belonging to trifluoromethyl groups. The definition of the metal coordination environment in metal–organic compounds featuring metal–organofluorine interactions is complicated by the broad range of interatomic distances spanned by these interactions. In this work, we use 3.6 and 2.9 Å as threshold values for Rb–F and Sr–F contacts, respectively. These values were selected on the basis of (i) previous crystal-chemical studies of rubidium–manganese­(II) and strontium trifluoroacetates, and (ii) density-functional calculations that reveal weak Rb–F noncovalent interactions at distances as large as 3.59 Å. Metal–oxygen and metal–fluorine distances given in define the metal coordination polyhedra. Organofluorine coordinates to rubidium in all three bimetallic trifluoroacetates. In the case of the alkaline-earth metal, only strontium–organofluorine interactions are observed; magnesium and calcium are coordinated by oxygen only. The range of rubidium–organofluorine distances listed in spans ca. 0.60 Å, reflecting the ability of the −CF3 group to establish interactions of varying strength with the alkali metal. This ability contributes to the versatility of trifluoroacetato as a ligand. This versatility, which was also observed in bimetallic alkali–manganese­(II) trifluoroacetates, should be further exploited to extend the palette of extended inorganic hybrids in terms of metal pairs, metal ratios, and structural motifs.

Thermal analysis was used to probe the chemical purity of polycrystalline trifluoroacetates. TGA and DTA curves are shown in . Experimental weight losses of ∼70.5 and 61.9 wt % are obtained for Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O and RbCa­(tfa)3, respectively. These numbers agree well with the expected weight losses for the decomposition of these bimetallic trifluoroacetates to the corresponding mixed-metal fluorides RbMgF3 (71.7 wt %) and RbCaF3 (60.7 wt %). PXRD confirms that these are the decomposition products (vide infra). In the case of Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O, the weight loss up to 160 °C is 14.2 wt %, in excellent agreement with what can be expected for the loss of one tfaH molecule and three H2O molecules. On the basis of the agreement between experimental and theoretical weight losses, we conclude that the chemical compositions of bimetallic fluoroacetate single crystals are representative of those of the polycrystalline samples. Inspection of the exothermic peaks in the DTA curves of Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O and RbCa­(tfa)3 hybrids shows that crystallization of inorganic fluorides begins at 255 and 266 °C, respectively, with no additional exotherms observed up to 600 °C. This observation highlights the potential of trifluoromethyl groups as mild fluorinating agents. The experimental weight loss observed for RbSr2(tfa)5 is ∼60.7 wt %. This value is larger than the 56.9 wt % expected for the decomposition of the hybrid into the corresponding mixture of RbF and SrF2. We attribute this difference to the deliquescent nature of RbSr2(tfa)5, which leads to hydration and partial decomposition of the trifluoroacetate during handling prior to thermal analysis. PXRD shows that RbSr2(tfa)5 decomposes to crystalline SrF2 upon heating to 600 °C (see Figure S6). Evolved gas analysis was performed on RbCa­(tfa)3 to gain insight regarding the fate of the fluoroacetate ligands upon solid-state decomposition. Evolved gases are identified as CO2, CO, (CF3CO)2O, C2F4, and CF3COOH (see Figure S7). Previous studies of the solid-state decomposition of monometallic trifluoroacetates reported similar gaseous products. In the case of RbCa­(tfa)3, CO2 and CO are the major products. CF3COOH likely forms due to the presence of residual water in the product and/or adventitious water in the thermal analyzer. Neither HF (m/z = 20) nor CF3COF (m/z = 116) are detected. More importantly, gas evolution is observed in a narrow temperature window (267–287 °C) that matches the weight loss during which RbCaF3 crystallizes. This finding highlights the potential of RbCa­(tfa)3 as a single-source precursor to the corresponding mixed-metal fluoride.

elements.content: The utility of Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O and RbCa­(tfa)3 as self-fluorinating, single-source precursors was confirmed by PXRD analysis of their solid-state decomposition products. Rietveld analyses of the PXRD patterns of the products obtained after decomposing Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O (800 °C, 60 min) and RbCa­(tfa)3 (600 °C, 15 min) under flowing nitrogen are shown in ; additional details are given in the Supporting Information (see Tables S17 and S18). Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O decomposes to hexagonal RbMgF3 (PDF No. 010-76-0179; P63/mmc; a = 5.83401 (9), c = 14.20170 (11) Å) and RbCa­(tfa)3 decomposes to cubic RbCaF3 (PDF No. 000-22-1265; Pm3̅m; a = 4.4547 (3) Å). The 1:1 Rb:Mg and Rb:Ca molar ratio in the trifluoroacetate precursor is encountered in the corresponding decomposition product. Crystalline MgO (PDF No. 010-71-1176) is observed as a minor phase (∼5 wt %). In other words, Rb–Mg and Rb–Ca bimetallic trifluoroacetates decompose to the fluoroperovskite phase in nearly quantitative yield without an external fluorinating agent. This finding and the purity of Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O and RbCa­(tfa)3 demonstrate that these bimetallic trifluoroacetates function as self-fluorinating single-source precursors for the solid-state synthesis of mixed-metal fluorides. They deliver the alkali and alkaline-earth metals in the desired stoichiometric ratio, and they also act as fluorinating agents via thermolysis of the trifluoromethyl groups.

elements.content: In the course of our reactivity studies, we discovered that thermolysis of Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O enables access to the two polymorphs of the RbMgF3 fluoroperovskite. Owing to its Goldschmidt tolerance factor (1.05), cubic and hexagonal polymorphs have been reported in the literature. Both structural variations are of interest as optical materials (e.g., lenses, radiation detectors). Unlike thermolysis in the solid state, decomposition of Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O in a mixture of high-boiling point organic solvents yields cubic RbMgF3. This is illustrated in a, where PXRD analysis of the decomposition product demonstrates that diffraction maxima can be indexed to cubic RbMgF3 (PDF No. 010-77-1575; Pm3̅m; a = 4.07782 (18) Å). The broadness of the diffraction maxima reveals that cubic RbMgF3 consists of nanocrystallites. An average crystalline domain size of ∼24 nm was estimated. Additional details of Rietveld analysis are given in the Supporting Information (Table S19). Cubic RbMgF3 resulting from solution thermolysis of Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O transforms to hexagonal RbMgF3 upon heating at 700 °C for 60 min under flowing nitrogen (see Figure S8). A similar cubic-to-hexagonal transition has been reported for perovskites such as SrMnO3, which have a tolerance factor slightly larger than 1 (1.1 for SrMnO3). Using Rietveld analysis of PXRD data, the cubic-to-hexagonal transition temperature window for RbMgF3 was estimated to be 600–650 °C (see Figure S8 and Table S20). We should mention that differential scanning calorimetric analyses performed at heating rates ranging from 1 to 50 °C min–1 did not allow us to pinpoint the exact cubic-to-hexagonal transition temperature, indicating comparable stability of both phases. Hexagonal RbMgF3 is the thermodynamically stable phase, and cubic RbMgF3 appears to be a metastable phase whose formation is favored by solution decomposition (i.e., a kinetic product). The reactivity of Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O is summarized in b.

elements.content: In summary, bimetallic trifluoroacetates Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6(tfaH)2­·3H2O, RbCa­(tfa)3, and RbSr2(tfa)5 were synthesized, and their crystal structures and reactivity were established. Metal–oxygen–metal bridges in Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O were found within four-metal building blocks. In contrast, RbCa­(tfa)3 and RbSr2(tfa)5 were extended inorganic hybrids in which infinite metal–oxygen–metal connectivity occurred in three and two dimensions, respectively. Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O and RbCa­(tfa)3 were shown to serve as self-fluorinating single-source precursors to RbMgF3 and RbCaF3, respectively. Trifluoromethyl groups belonging to the trifluoroacetato ligands acted as a built-in fluorine source. Our findings show that, although counterintuitive because of their geometrically rigid nature, halogenated monocarboxylates can be used as bridging ligands to generate bimetallic organic–inorganic hybrids featuring infinite connectivity of the metals. Additionally, the resulting hybrid crystals serve as self-fluorinating, single-source precursors to the corresponding mixed-metal fluorides, eliminating the need for a corrosive fluorinated liquid or gas at high temperature or pressure. The versatility of the trifluoroacetato ligand may be further exploited to extend the palette of bimetallic fluorinated hybrids in terms of metal pairs, metal ratios, structural motifs, and reactivity patterns.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, bimetallic trifluoroacetates Rb2Mg2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅3H2O, RbCa(tfa)3, and RbSr2(tfa)5 were synthesized, and their crystal structures and reactivity were established. Metal-oxygen-metal bridges in Rb2Mg2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅3H2O were found within four-metal building blocks. In contrast, RbCa(tfa)3 and RbSr2(tfa)5 were extended inorganic hybrids in which infinite metal-oxygen-metal connectivity occurred in three and two dimensions, respectively. Rb2Mg2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅3H2O and RbCa(tfa)3 were shown to serve as self-fluorinating single-source precursors to RbMgF3 and RbCaF3, respectively. Trifluoromethyl groups belonging to the trifluoroacetato ligands acted as a built-in fluorine source. Our findings show that, although counterintuitive because of their geometrically rigid nature, halogenated monocarboxylates can be used as bridging ligands to generate bimetallic organic-inorganic hybrids featuring infinite connectivity of the metals. Additionally, the resulting hybrid crystals serve as self-fluorinating, single-source precursors to the corresponding mixed-metal fluorides, eliminating the need for a corrosive fluorinated liquid or gas at high temperature or pressure. The versatility of the trifluoroacetato ligand may be further exploited to extend the palette of bimetallic fluorinated hybrids in terms of metal pairs, metal ratios, structural motifs, and reactivity patterns.

cln_elements.content: Decomposition of the bimetallic trifluoroacetates in the solid state was carried out in a tube furnace under flowing nitrogen (100–220 mL min–1). ∼5–20 mg of sample were placed in an alumina boat, and the temperature was ramped at a rate of 10 °C min–1. Target temperatures and dwelling times were 800 °C for 60 min (Mg), 600 °C for 15 min (Ca), and 600 °C for 60 min (Sr). In the case of rubidium–strontium trifluoroacetate, thermal analyses and solid-state decomposition experiments were conducted on polycrystalline samples synthesized using a starting mixture containing 0.25 mmol of Rb2CO3, 1 mmol of SrCO3, 1.5 mL of CF3COOH, and 1.5 mL of double-distilled water.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Solid-State Decomposition

Decomposition of the bimetallic trifluoroacetates in the solid state was carried out in a tube furnace under flowing nitrogen (100-220 mL min-1). ~5-20 mg of sample were placed in an alumina boat, and the temperature was ramped at a rate of 10 °C min-1. Target temperatures and dwelling times were 800 °C for 60 min (Mg), 600 °C for 15 min (Ca), and 600 °C for 60 min (Sr). In the case of rubidium-strontium trifluoroacetate, thermal analyses and solid-state decomposition experiments were conducted on polycrystalline samples synthesized using a starting mixture containing 0.25 mmol of Rb2CO3, 1 mmol of SrCO3, 1.5 mL of CF3COOH, and 1.5 mL of double-distilled water.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structures of (a, b) Rb2Mg2(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O, (c, d) RbCa­(tfa)3, and (e–g) RbSr2(tfa)5. Four-metal building blocks (a) and extended perspective (b) are shown for Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O. Infinite calcium chains connected by Rb–O/F polyhedra in RbCa­(tfa)3 are depicted in (c) and (d). Corrugated sheets of Sr–O/F polyhedra (e) forming 10-membered rings (f) are shown for RbSr2(tfa)5; rubidium atoms sit above and below these sheets (g). Unit cells are depicted with solid lines. Atom splitting in disordered positions has been omitted for clarity; only major occupancy sites are shown. Hydrogen bonds in Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O are depicted with dashed gray lines.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structures of (a, b) Rb2Mg2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅3H2O, (c, d) RbCa(tfa)3, and (e-g) RbSr2(tfa)5. Four-metal building blocks (a) and extended perspective (b) are shown for Rb2Mg2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅3H2O. Infinite calcium chains connected by Rb-O/F polyhedra in RbCa(tfa)3 are depicted in (c) and (d). Corrugated sheets of Sr-O/F polyhedra (e) forming 10-membered rings (f) are shown for RbSr2(tfa)5; rubidium atoms sit above and below these sheets (g). Unit cells are depicted with solid lines. Atom splitting in disordered positions has been omitted for clarity; only major occupancy sites are shown. Hydrogen bonds in Rb2Mg2(tfa)6(tfaH)2⋅3H2O are depicted with dashed gray lines.

cln_elements.content: Rb–Mg and Rb–Ca trifluoroacetates function as self-fluorinating single-source precursors for the solid-state synthesis of mixed-metal fluorides RbMgF3 and RbCaF3, respectively. Shown in this figure are Rietveld analyses of the PXRD patterns of the solid-state decomposition products of (a) Rb2Mg2­(tfa)6­(tfaH)2­·3H2O and (b) RbCa­(tfa)3. Experimental data (black spheres), calculated patterns (red lines), and difference curves (blue lines) are shown. Green tick marks correspond to the fluoroperovskite RbMgF3 or RbCaF3. Magenta tick marks in (a) correspond to MgO.

Experimental data (black spheres), calculated patterns (red lines), and difference curves (blue lines) are shown. Green tick marks correspond to the fluoroperovskite RbMgF3 or RbCaF3. metadata.title:
Rubidium–Alkaline-Earth Trifluoroacetate Hybrids
as Self-Fluorinating Single-Source Precursors to Mixed-Metal Fluorides
